byline.contributor: Doris Burke contributed research from New York.

abstract: Rank-and-file employees are often hit hardest when startups, even very promising ones, founder or are acquired; trend is exemplified by Good Technology, which was sold for less than half its private valuation to BlackBerry, leaving most employees with net loss given fact they had paid heavy taxes on their options; venture capital backers and executives are often granted protection from such losses.
lead_paragraph: Employees at Good Technology, once valued at $1.1 billion, found their shares made practically worthless by a sale to BlackBerry for $425 million.

headline.main: When a Unicorn Start-Up Stumbles, Its Employees Get Hurt
headline.print_headline: When a Unicorn Stumbles, the Employees Get Hurt

snippet: Employees at Good Technology, once valued at $1.1 billion, found their shares made practically worthless by a sale to BlackBerry for $425 million.
